text.script: def test_ld_no(expect,ans): import ast import numpy as np if (ans=='No') or (ans=='NO') or (ans=='no'): ret['ok'] = True return ret list_expect = ast.literal_eval('[[1,-1,3,4,5],[0,0,0,0,0],[-3,3,3,5,1]]') list_vec = [] for vec in list_expect: list_vec.append(np.array(vec)) list_scalars = [float(s) for s in ans.split(',')] ret = {'ok':False} # check scalars are not all zero max_sca = max(list_scalars) min_sca = min(list_scalars) if (max_sca == 0) and (min_sca ==0): ret['msg'] = 'Your answer should contain at least one non-zero scalar.' return ret # check there are enough scalars if (len(list_scalars) != 2): ret['msg'] = 'Your answer contains too many/too few scalars.' return ret ret['msg'] = 'Your linear combination does not equal the zero polynomial.' return ret
text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] be the vector space of polynomials with real coefficients in the variable [mathjaxinline]t[/mathjaxinline]. Consider the list of vectors [mathjaxinline]\{ f; g\}[/mathjaxinline], where [mathjaxinline]f(t) = 1+t[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]g(t) = t+t^2[/mathjaxinline] are vectors in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline].

Can you find scalars [mathjaxinline]a_1, a_2[/mathjaxinline], not both zero, such that [mathjaxinline]a_1f + a_2 g = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]? If so, enter an example of such scalars below. If not, type ‘No'.
Is the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2\}[/mathjaxinline] linearly dependent or linearly independent?

font.p: We cannot find scalars [mathjaxinline]a_1, a_2[/mathjaxinline], not both zero, such that [mathjaxinline]a_1f + a_2 g = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]. If [mathjaxinline]a_1 \ne 0[/mathjaxinline], then [mathjaxinline]a_1 f[/mathjaxinline] will have a non-zero constant term, and [mathjaxinline]a_2 g[/mathjaxinline] must have a zero constant term, so [mathjaxinline]a_1 f + a_2g[/mathjaxinline] will have a non-zero constant term and therefore not be the zero polynomial.

Similarly, if [mathjaxinline]a_2 \ne 0[/mathjaxinline], then [mathjaxinline]a_2 g[/mathjaxinline] will have a non-zero [mathjaxinline]t^2[/mathjaxinline] term, whereas [mathjaxinline]a_1 f[/mathjaxinline] cannot have a [mathjaxinline]t^2[/mathjaxinline] term, so [mathjaxinline]a_1 f + a_2g[/mathjaxinline] will have a non-zero [mathjaxinline]t^2[/mathjaxinline] term and therefore not be the zero polynomial.
Note that we cannot set [mathjaxinline]a_1 = -t[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]a_2 = 1[/mathjaxinline], since [mathjaxinline]-t[/mathjaxinline] is not a scalar.
